todos.title: Anagram
todos.body: Word or phrase formed by rearranging another word or phrase.

todos.title: Perceptual Learning
todos.body: Using your gut instinct to solve problems (third eye).

todos.title: Scaffolding
todos.body: Pulling aspects from different experiences to solve problems.

todos.title: Distractions
todos.body: It takes people an average of 25 minutes to return to a task once interrupted.

todos.title: Focus v. Concentration
todos.body: Focus is the ability to stay in the moment; concentration is the ability to look at the big picture in front of you.  Both can be damaged by distractions.  Self confidence is one of the greatest tools for focusing.

todos.title: Six Skills for Working Faster and Smarter
todos.body: Focus and concentration, increasing mental capacity, thinking outside box, organization, and forgetting.

todos.title: Think Outside the Box
todos.body: Break the rules.

todos.title: Art of Making Yourself Memorable
todos.body: As knowledge increases, creativity tapers off.  People do not remember the normal, they like to remembers the unexpected.

todos.title: Don't Be Detail Oriented
todos.body: Your brain will remember much more if you don't try to grab every single detail.

todos.title: Forgetting
todos.body: Your brain must be able to distinguish between high quality and low quality.  Ditch and forget the unimportant.  Be selective.

todos.title: Absent Abstract
todos.body: You cannot remember anything if it is abstract to you.  You must associate it with something you already know or remember.  Bringing a sense of silliness or absurdness helps memory.   All memory must have some form of mental imagery.

todos.title: Pattern Retention
todos.body: When you see patterns reoccurring, store that information as valuable and discard the rest.

todos.title: Brain Exercise
todos.body: When we exercise our brain we stimulate new neurons.

todos.title: Internal v. External Distractor
todos.body: We distract ourselves just as much as other people, internet, emails, social media, distract us.  Beware of the monkey mind.

todos.title: Habits
todos.body: Things we repeatedly do everyday.  Most commercial products are successful because they leverage people's existing habits.  Force yourself to look for patterns in people.  Noticing the way people react will teach you how to engage with them to reach your goals.

todos.title: Pattern
todos.body: Theme of recurring events.  Identifying patterns is what helps us to predict the future and consolidate information to free up more space for learning.  Patterns can only be found within context.

todos.title: Real World Experiences
todos.body: The person who can cull from a myriad of real world experiences in life is often the one who will find a more precise answer.

todos.title: Relearn
todos.body: The illiterate of the 21st century will be those that cannot learn, unlearn, and relearn (Alan Toffler).

todos.title: Technology
todos.body: Technologies like Google and calculators can cause our brains to become very lazy in certain areas.  Strive to be able to process things internally, not by looking them up.

todos.title: Making it Stick
todos.body: Simplicity, unexpectedness, concreteness, emotions, and storytelling.

todos.title: Stroop Test
todos.body: Say the following colors ' a. Black, b. Gray, c. Gray, d. Black.  If you say black instead of Gray for 'c' you are good at focusing.

todos.title: Remembering Names
todos.body: Requires original awareness, ask them to repeat it, ask them to spell it, associate it with something physically outstanding related to them and silly.

todos.title: Stories
todos.body: People remember stories.

todos.title: Focus
todos.body: Our ability to focus is located in the prefrontal cortex of the brain which is the mot delicate, impatient, and energy hungry part of the brain.

todos.title: Power of Forgetting
todos.body: Only when we forget can we learn more.

todos.title: Retroactive Inhibition
todos.body: Not allowing information to soak in.  Occurs when you learn something new and then quickly shift to another activity.

todos.title: Making Daily Habits
todos.body: Make what you want to achieve and how you should achieve it a habit.  For example, if rule breaking is something that is important to creativity, make rule breaking a daily habit.

todos.title: Memory Palace
todos.body: Imaginary place where you can go to recall information.

todos.title: Multi-Tasking
todos.body: Humans cannot focus and be attentive on more than one thing at a time.  The only way we can do more than one task at a time is if we are focusing on one task and are not really paying attention to the other task or if our mind goes back and forth real quickly.  Focus and attention must be done sequentially and cannot be done in parallel.

todos.title: Unconventional Thinking
todos.body: Create a culture of unconventional thinking.

todos.title: Chunk Thoughts
todos.body: Chunk thoughts and associate them with a single word.

todos.title: Wasted Time
todos.body: Average worker wastes three hours per eight-hour workday because or lack of focus, interruptions, internet, socializing, emails, etc.

todos.title: Emails
todos.body: Average person looks at email 36 times an hour.  It takes more than a minute to return to a task once looking at an email.  Don't let your e-mail pop-up and only answer emails twice a day.

todos.title: Original Awareness
todos.body: Anything which you are originally aware of cannot be forgotten.  Original awareness takes focus and deliberate intention.  You must also manufacture associations that have a significant meaning to you.

todos.title: Memorable Impression
todos.body: A lie can get halfway around the world before the truth can even get its boots on (Mark Twain).  People love urban legends, conspiracy theories, and bogus scare tactics.

todos.title: Law of Compounding Errors
todos.body: A huge error tends to be greater than the sum of all the small errors that caused it.
